channel.name: What are the main challenges for increasing Mina TPS and reducing finality time?

messages.content:
Why couldn't we arbitrarily increase the number of transactions in a tree in the scan state from 4 to say 10,000?

Does the height of the tree is the main factor that determines how fast a block can be processed?

Could we change the consensus algorithm for faster finality?
Finality is very different from other PoS chains because it’s Ouroboros
There is a paper called ledger combiners IIRC that improves it algorithmically
But the speed of the blockchain is essentially controlled by network bandwidth, latency, and how long it takes to prove
Finality really isn’t that important when you have preconditions and atomic transactions

Regarding the "how long it takes to prove" part, is my assumption about the height of the tree being the main factor for how long it takes to reduce it to a single proof? I think that would make it O(log(n)), which would seem like an argument in favor of increasing the transactions in the scan state by a lot.

Also I would expect that bandwidth and latency shouldn't be  a big issue for MIna, since the proof of the root state is small and fast to verify.

Could you expand on finality, preconditions, and atomic transactions?
You have events though
Finality is no different from Bitcoin
Preconditions make it UTXO-like
If you craft your transactions well, you don’t have to worry about rollups
A la payment/state channels
Even without it, the core example you want is that of me sending money to you, and you then sending to me.
How do you make sure a rollback invalidates the second along with the first? Make the second depend on the first via receipt chain hash.
It would be a bit more convenient if Mina was true UTXO, but alas, it’s still OK
Atomic transactions are that you can have many account updates in your transaction
Of course the limit is quite low unfortunately
Handling receipts and state channels seem to lead to really bad UX or to the users putting a lot of trust on some operator to get fast/good UX tho
Why would it be better to have UTXOs? Doesn't this increases state size and verification time by a lot, and goes against some of the core Mina advantages?
How do events fit in this topic?

Assuming finality is no different from Bitcoin, I wonder then why at least we can't include hundreds of thousands of transactions in a Mina block. In Bitcoin this isn't possible because this would result in huge blocks that would be hard to propagate and slow to verify, but in Mina we have the advantage of being able to propagate the small root proof of the whole state, extremely fast, and verify any single account state with just the small proof and the witness of that state, also extremely fast
Not if you do it right
No?
Events can blow up size of transactions a bit
Not true entirely
You still need to distribute the transactions for consensus
Otherwise you wouldn’t know what’s under the hash
Of course not _everyone_ needs to see the transactions, but the same is true on Bitcoin.
Yes, but then although finality remains slow, you increase TPS by a lot
The security of the consensus relies on how fast the honest stake sees everything

Hey, revisiting this and I wonder, don't you only need to distribute the state and the proof that validates that state? And security of the consensus only relies on how fast the honest stake sees these, even if they never see the actual transactions? Or am I missing something?
Good question
But events and actions exist
And other block producers need to have the underlying data to prove new transactions on it

As I understand, the main time-critical task is to verify the txs proofs (that can be done in parallel) and build a block; the proof for the block can calculated later.

Therefore, I do not see significant technical obstacles to increasing the TPS and decreasing the time between blocks, subject to changing memory requirements for the nodes.

Haven't thought about these. I just wonder how much throughput Mina could get away with, with least lost of decentralization, since going back to Lighting, another thing that always seemed kind of dreadful, was how fast queues would grow and how much time it would take to clear them if most users opened a channel, which I guess the analogy for Mina would be users depositing to a zkApp/L2 (although fortunately in Mina once you deposit to a zkApp/L2, you immediately get connected to all the other depositors of the same zkApp/L2, and zkApps/L2s can open "channels" with each other, so you avoid a lot of the Lighting routing complexity).

I think that increasing TPS would actually lead to increasing block time, since the more transactions you want to prove, the more levels you add to the tree, and if I understand correctly, you can't start processing a level until you have processed its children

I think you are missing an important detail, you don't have the proof of latest state in latest block. The proving work is delayed few blocks and therefore the node needs to validate the new state manually.
Not really, it would just delay the work even further.

Couldn't we turn this around and let the current block leader coordinate the workers to prove and reduce all transactions into the new state, so it only needs to share the new proof and state updates?
Since bandwidth is a hard limit, but parallelized proving can scale horizontally

Although I think this would probably only work if each block producer handles its own workers and there wasn't a snarketplace, which would increase the requirements to be a block producer.

The current architecture certainly maximizes for decentralization and I love that. I'm just thinking about potential future bottlenecks and how to overcome them, but it's likely that the Mina designers already thought about all of this and the current design is the optimal, and sharing the whole transactions in new blocks for manual validation scales fine and the tradeoff of increasing the requirements for block producers isn't worth it.

Just another question. Is the network using a block size near the max bandwidth limit for stable block propagation or why isn't the TPS higher?

Thanks to everyone for your feedback! :Mina_Spectrum: :Mina_Mainnet_Toast:

> Just another question. Is the network using a block size near the max bandwidth limit for stable block propagation or why isn't the TPS higher?
I don't know how the current config was picked, but I doubt that it's the bandwidth limit.
Nevertheless AFAICT the blocks are currently not full.

Yep, it's more of a future concern, since [1 TPS](https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/831853570260336640/1255277205223899238) seems quite low, and it would be nice for the network to be ready to handle a sudden increased demand for block space. Maybe even a dynamic block size could help like in Monero, if something like that is not already in place.

I would like Mina becoming like a global bank similar to Bitcoin (and even more decentralized, with higher throughput, and feature rich) where anyone could have an account on the L1, even if finality is slow, like I described in this [post](https://x.com/ChrlyzXChrlyz/status/1822106083386880452)
